Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\) where L is a linear differential operator. We explore the impact of a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) applied to \\(u\\), resulting in \\(\\hat{u}(k, t)\\), and its subsequent evolution.

If the Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) is applied to the function \\( u(x, 0) \\) at t = 0, and then the transformed function \\(\\hat{u}(k, t)\\) is evolved under \\(\\frac{\\partial \\hat{u}}{\\partial t} = L\\hat{u}\\) without any intervention, will \\(\\hat{u}(k, T)\\) at T = t be the same as if \\( u(x, t) \\) was directly transformed at T = t?
Explanation: The evolution of \\(\\hat{u}(k, t)\\) after the Fourier transform and its direct transformation at any later time T will yield the same results due to the linearity of the differential operator and the properties of the Fourier transform preserving the dynamics of the system under linear operations.
